Let $k(N)$ denote the size of the largest set $A\subseteq \{1,\ldots,N\}$ such that the sets\[S_r = \{ a_1+\cdots +a_r : a_1<\cdots<a_r\in A\}\]are disjoint for distinct $r\geq 1$. Estimate $k(N)$ - in particular, is it true that $k(N)\sim 2N^{1/2}$?



Straus \cite{St66} calls such sets admissible, and proved that\[\limsup \frac{k(N)}{N^{1/2}}\leq \frac{4}{\sqrt{3}}=2.309\cdots,\]and that $A=(N-k,N]\cap \mathbb{N}$ has this property for $k=2m-1$ if $N\in [m^2,m^2+m)$ and for $k=2m$ if $N\in [m^2+m,(m+1)^2)$, which implies that\[\liminf \frac{k(N)}{N^{1/2}}\geq 2.\]Erd\H{o}s, Nicolas, and S\'{a}rk\"{o}zy \cite{ENS91} improved the upper bound to\[\limsup \frac{k(N)}{N^{1/2}}\leq (143/27)^{1/2}=2.301\cdots.\]The conjecture was proved (for all large $N$) by Deshouillers and Freiman \cite{DeFr99}, who further show that in some cases the largest such $A$ has the form $(N-k,N]\cap \mathbb{N}$ as above.

See also [186] and [789]. For an infinite version of this problem see [875].




References


[DeFr99] Deshouillers, Jean-Marc and Freiman, Gregory A., On an additive problem of Erd\H{o}s and {S}traus. {II}. Ast\'{e}risque (1999), xii, 141--148.

[ENS91] Erd\H{o}s, P. and Nicolas, J.-L. and S\'{a}rk\"ozy, A., Sommes de sous-ensembles. S\'{e}m. Th\'{e}or. Nombres Bordeaux (2) (1991), 55--72.

[St66] Straus, E. G., On a problem in combinatorial number theory. J. Math. Sci. (1966), 77--80.
